docs.lead_paragraph: A key front in the effort to reform the N.C.A.A. is medical coverage for college athletes, some of whom have become burdened with costs to treat their injuries.

headline.main: A Fight to Keep College Athletes From the Pain of Injury Costs
headline.print_headline: A Fight to Save College Athletes From the Ordeal of Injury Costs

docs.abstract: Medical care for injured athletes has emerged as a key front in sprawling battle to reform the NCAA; hope is to ensure that current and former athletes never pay out of pocket for sports injuries; under current NCAA rules, players can still lose their scholarships after being hurt, often pay for their own insurance and are generally responsible for long-term health care for injuries sustained on the playing field.
docs.snippet: A key front in the effort to reform the N.C.A.A. is medical coverage for college athletes, some of whom have become burdened with costs to treat their injuries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Repairing the state’s troubled website would be far more expensive in a year when the Democratic governor, John Kitzhaber, is already dealing with political fallout.

headline.main: Oregon Panel Recommends Switch to Federal Health Exchange
headline.print_headline: Oregon Panel Recommends Switch to Federal Health Exchange

docs.abstract: Oregon panel, with encouragement from Obama administration, recommends state scrap website for its beleaguered health insurance exchange and use federal marketplace instead; repairing state’s troubled website would be far more expensive in year when the Democratic governor, John Kitzhaber, is already dealing with political fallout.
docs.snippet: Repairing the state’s troubled website would be far more expensive in a year when the Democratic governor, John Kitzhaber, is already dealing with political fallout.

byline.contributor: Robert Pear reported from Washington, and Kirk Johnson from Seattle.
byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and KIRK JOHNSON

docs.lead_paragraph: Lisa Keller is a mother, a runner, a lifelong Alaskan and a cancer survivor. She says she has health insurance again because of Mark Begich, her Democratic senator.
docs.snippet: Lisa Keller is a mother, a runner, a lifelong Alaskan and a cancer survivor. She says she has health insurance again because of Mark Begich, her Democratic senator.

docs.lead_paragraph: The NCAA's board of directors took the first step toward shifting power to the five largest football conferences on Thursday, endorsing a 57-page plan that calls for giving 65 of the nation's biggest schools more autonomy in how to fund scholarships, handle health care and decide other increasingly hot-button issues involving their athletes.

headline.main: NCAA Board Endorses More Power for Big Schools

docs.lead_paragraph: Oregon, once expected to be a national leader in the federal health care overhaul, on Thursday moved to become the first state to dump its troubled online health exchange and use the federal marketplace instead.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers have again turned away efforts to expand the state Medicaid program under the federal health care law, with the Senate health committee voting 6 to 2 on Wednesday against an expansion.

headline.main: Louisiana: Medicaid Expansion Is Rejected Again
headline.print_headline: Louisiana: Medicaid Expansion Is Rejected Again

docs.abstract: Louisiana lawmakers again turn away efforts to expand state's Medicaid program under the federal health care law, with the Senate health committee voting 6 to 2 against such an expansion.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new cost estimate could help state officials and others pushing for the expansion of Medicaid undue the Affordable Care Act.

headline.main: Forecast Cut on Spending for Health
headline.print_headline: Forecast Cut on Spending for Health

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office reduces from $70 billion to $46 billion its estimate of how much more states will spend on Medicaid in coming decade because of Affordable Care Act; new cost estimate could help state officials and others pushing for Medicaid expansion.
docs.snippet: The new cost estimate could help state officials and others pushing for the expansion of Medicaid undue the Affordable Care Act.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amedisys, one of the nation’s largest home health providers, will pay $150 million to resolve accusations that it inflated Medicare billings, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.

headline.main: Amedisys to Pay $150 Million in Medicare Billing Case
headline.print_headline: Amedisys to Pay $150 Million in Medicare Billing Case

docs.abstract: Amedisys, one of the nation's largest home health providers, will pay $150 million to resolve accusations that it inflated Medicare billings and had improper financial relationships with referring physicians.
docs.snippet: Amedisys, one of the nation’s largest home health providers, will pay $150 million to resolve accusations that it inflated Medicare billings, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: As they work more closely with our mobile computers, devices that once simply fixed whatever ailed us will begin to do much more.

headline.seo: App-Controlled Hearing Aid Improves Even Normal Hearing
headline.main: Conjuring Images of a Bionic Future
headline.print_headline: Conjuring Images of a Bionic Future

docs.abstract: Farhad Manjoo State of the Art column highlights advances in hearing aid technology that allow users to control their hearing aids using their smart phones; contends it is only a slight exaggeration to say that new crop of advanced hearing aids can perform just as well or better than the ears many are born with.
docs.snippet: As they work more closely with our mobile computers, devices that once simply fixed whatever ailed us will begin to do much more.
